edu.ncsu.csc.Galant.algorithm.code.macro

Class Macro

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.ncsu.csc.Galant.algorithm.code.macro.Macro
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    ParameterizedMacro, SimpleReplacementMacro

    public abstract class Macro
extends java.lang.Object

    The super class for any macro that replaces some section of algorithm code with proper Java code.

    For now, macros should not change the number of lines in the code, to keep the line numbers in error diagnostics correct

    To do:
    this does not appear to work in case of multi-line function definitions

    Each macro has a Pattern that is used to find relevant sections of the user's code. Matcher.appendReplacement(StringBuffer, String) and Matcher.appendTail(StringBuffer) are used to construct a modified version of the code with a StringBuffer.

    There are two subclasses:

    1. SimpleReplacementMacro - used for simple text replacement.
    2. ParameterizedMacro - used for anything that looks like a function with parameters; any number of parameters, including an unspecified number, can be specified; the "name(param_1, ..., param_k)" construct may or may not be followed by a code block enclosed in {}'s; a special case is "function name(args)"

      • MACROS

        public static final java.util.List<Macro> MACROS
        A list of all the macros that can be used in algorithm code. Note: if you want to add a macro dynamically (e.g., from within another macro), use GENERATED_MACROS.

      • modify

        protected abstract java.lang.String modify(java.lang.String code,
                                           java.util.regex.MatchResult match)
                                    throws MalformedMacroException

        Subclasses should implement this method and return a modified version of the current match. The returned string will be used as a replacement string for Matcher.appendReplacement(StringBuffer, String), with the syntax described in the javadoc for that method. So backslashes and dollar signs may need to be escaped.

        If the match is not actually correct, null can be returned. (This can be used with the default applyTo without creating an infinite loop.)

        Note: Macros may add new macros to the end of the macro list (e.g., by creating new macros), but other modifications to the list may not be supported.

        Parameters:
        code - the user code on which this macro is being applied.
        match - a match of this macro's pattern.
        Returns:
        the replacement of the matched region, or null if the match is not actually valid.
        Throws:
        MalformedMacroException - if the match is not a valid invocation of this macro, but it should have been.

      • applyTo

        public java.lang.String applyTo(java.lang.String code)
                         throws MalformedMacroException
        Applies this macro to the given code. For each match found, replaces the match with the result of modify(String, MatchResult) (if it's not null), then searches for the next match starting at the index immediately after the first character of the current match in the modified code. So if the result of modify produces a match, that match will be included.
        Parameters:
        code - the code to apply this macro to.
        Returns:
        the version of the code after this macro has been applied.
        Throws:
        MalformedMacroException
